articles.headline: Scenes from Kharkiv: Battle wreckage, the boom of artillery, and people sheltering in the subway.
articles.snippet: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The thuds of artillery start as a low-decibel rumble, but rattle the rib cage as you get closer. A crossroads at the northern entrance of Kharkiv is about as close to the front lines as anyone would wish to be on Friday, as Ukrainian soldiers waged a fierce battle to push Russian forces away from the city.

articles.headline: Ukraine and the Mirage of Energy Independence
articles.snippet: Domestic oil and gas production in the U.S. boomed in recent years. But the country and its allies remain reluctant to impose sanctions on Russian energy that would damage their economies.
articles.abstract: Domestic oil and gas production in the U.S. boomed in recent years. But the country and its allies remain reluctant to impose sanctions on Russian energy that would damage their economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It may be time to pluck that old cardigan out of the closet.

articles.headline: ‘I’ll Stand on the Side of Russia’: Pro-Putin Sentiment Spreads Online
articles.snippet: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.
articles.abstract: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day before Russia invaded Ukraine, former President Donald J. Trump called the wartime strategy of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia “pretty smart.” His remarks were posted on YouTube, Twitter and the messaging app Telegram, where they were viewed more than 1.3 million times.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
articles.snippet: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
articles.abstract: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDYKA, Poland — Cradling her 3-year-old son, who was gravely ill with cancer, the 25-year-old Ukrainian mother staggered into Poland on Friday.

articles.headline: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
articles.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
articles.abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine braced for an all-out assault on its capital early Saturday, after a day in which the military blew up a bridge to slow the advance of Russian soldiers, street fights erupted in a northern district of the city, and the nation’s leaders warned residents that Russia wanted to “bring the capital to its knees.”
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Worried About Stocks? Think of Ukrainians Under Siege First.
articles.snippet: If you have an investment portfolio or own a home, you’ve probably experienced big gains. Here’s how to use those winnings to help.
articles.abstract: If you have an investment portfolio or own a home, you’ve probably experienced big gains. Here’s how to use those winnings to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, plenty of people have tried to predict what it will mean for gas prices or interest rates or your investments.

articles.headline: Does Anyone Know What Paper Towels Should Cost?
articles.snippet: Online shopping was supposed to give consumers more power and freedom. Instead, costs are so fluid that household goods fluctuate almost like Bitcoin.
articles.abstract: Online shopping was supposed to give consumers more power and freedom. Instead, costs are so fluid that household goods fluctuate almost like Bitcoin.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a holiday toy catalog from Amazon arrived in the mail in late October, Krista Hoffmann noticed something amiss.

articles.headline: Russia Intensifies Censorship Campaign, Pressuring Tech Giants
articles.snippet: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.
articles.abstract: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russia attacks Ukraine, the authorities in Moscow are intensifying a censorship campaign at home by squeezing some of the world’s biggest tech companies.

articles.headline: A Kennedy’s Crusade Against Covid Vaccines Anguishes Family and Friends
articles.snippet: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has risen to become a major figure in the vaccine resistance movement. Those close to him say it’s “heartbreaking.”
articles.abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has risen to become a major figure in the vaccine resistance movement. Those close to him say it’s “heartbreaking.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Kerry Kennedy remembers how much she admired her older brother Robert as they grew up in Hickory Hill, the family estate in McLean, Va. She still talks about how he took her along to ford streams, crawl through drainpipes and catch frogs and snakes, ignoring his friends who did not want a 6-year-old girl tagging behind on their outdoor adventures.

articles.headline: Putin’s War Ushers In Crisis for Russia
articles.snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
articles.abstract: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has ushered in a crisis for his country — in its economy and identity.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Biden and Putin, Children of the Cold War, Face Off in New Conflict
articles.snippet: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.
articles.abstract: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Biden tells the story, he was blunt with Vladimir V. Putin during a meeting in Moscow more than a decade ago. “I’m looking into your eyes, and I don’t think you have a soul,” Mr. Biden recalled telling the K.G.B. veteran. Mr. Putin smiled. “We understand one another,” he said.

articles.headline: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military, outmanned and outgunned, waged ferocious, close-range battles on Saturday to maintain control of the capital, Kyiv, and other cities around the country as intense street fighting broke out on the third day of the Russian invasion.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Eric Schmitt, Michael Levenson and The New York Times

articles.headline: ‘Everybody in Our Country Needs to Defend’
articles.snippet: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
articles.abstract: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Glass shards, bits of metal and shell casings, the detritus from a fierce and lethal street fight in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, lay scattered over hundreds of yards of pavement. Leading away from the site were bloody footprints.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: Why the Chinese Internet Is Cheering Russia’s Invasion
articles.snippet: As the world overwhelmingly condemns the assault on Ukraine, online opinion in China is mostly pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin.
articles.abstract: As the world overwhelmingly condemns the assault on Ukraine, online opinion in China is mostly pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: If President Vladimir V. Putin is looking for international support and approval for his invasion of Ukraine, he can turn to the Chinese internet.

articles.headline: A New Message for Police: If You See Something, Say Something
articles.snippet: Officers fear retaliation if they step in to stop misconduct by other officers. In the wake of George Floyd’s death, departments are trying to change that.
articles.abstract: Officers fear retaliation if they step in to stop misconduct by other officers. In the wake of George Floyd’s death, departments are trying to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — On an early Monday morning in a chilly classroom in Baltimore, a diverse group of recruits to one of the nation’s most troubled police departments gathered for a new kind of training. The screen flashed a photo of a man whose face is now familiar to the world.

articles.headline: BP to ‘Exit’ Stake in Russian Oil Giant Rosneft
articles.snippet: Russian holdings may become toxic for the Western oil industry.
articles.abstract: Russian holdings may become toxic for the Western oil industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The British oil giant BP said on Sunday that it would “exit” its nearly 20 percent stake in Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company, making it one of the first large companies to abandon Russia after its invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: ‘Blood Red’: How Lopsided New District Lines Are Deepening America’s Divide
articles.snippet: Competitive districts are disappearing in Texas and beyond. Consider the case of a once-rising Republican star, Dan Crenshaw, in the Houston suburbs.
articles.abstract: Competitive districts are disappearing in Texas and beyond. Consider the case of a once-rising Republican star, Dan Crenshaw, in the Houston suburbs.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE WOODLANDS, Texas — Representative Dan Crenshaw was tagged as a rising Republican star almost from the moment of his first victory: A conservative, Harvard-educated, ex-Navy SEAL who lost his right eye in Afghanistan, he bucked the 2018 suburban revolt against Donald J. Trump to win a House seat in the Houston suburbs.

articles.headline: Once Sleepy and Picturesque, Ukrainian Villages Mobilize for War
articles.snippet: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.
articles.abstract: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHOMUTYNTSI, Ukraine — The villagers appeared as silhouettes in the headlights of cars and trucks, a few carrying guns and others clubs, as if they were gangsters roaming the streets.

articles.headline: Ukraine Agrees to Talks With Russia, but Fighting Still Rages
articles.snippet: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.
articles.abstract: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As Russian forces bore down on Ukraine’s capital and officials put the toll of civilian dead at more than 350 since the invasion began, the two countries agreed Sunday to sit down for talks “without preconditions,” but hopes were not high for a peaceful resolution of the conflict.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: In Foreign Policy U-Turn, Germany Ups Military Spending and Arms Ukraine
articles.snippet: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It took an invasion of a sovereign country nearby, threats of nuclear attack, images of civilians facing off against Russian tanks and a spate of shaming from allies for Germany to shake its decades-long faith in a military-averse foreign policy that was born of the crimes of the Third Reich.

articles.headline: Putin Declares a Nuclear Alert, and Biden Seeks De-escalation
articles.snippet: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.
articles.abstract: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Vladimir V. Putin declared Sunday that he was putting his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness” — a heightened alert status reminiscent of some of the most dangerous moments of the Cold War — President Biden and his aides had a choice.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
